name: Razer DeathAdder V4 Pro Review
cons: Extremely expensive
Buttons are on the louder side and don’t sound great

name: SONY INZONE Mouse-A Review
pros: Interesting shape that isn’t a clone
Top-tier internals and great gaming performance
Buttons are well-implemented (but the switches aren’t as crispy as they should be)
cons: Scroll wheel is too light to press, leading to accidental presses while scrolling
Scroll wheel isn’t very grippy
Expensive (at MSRP)
Coating is prone to showing fingerprints

name: Logitech G Pro X Superlight 2c Review
pros: Refined compact design with a safe shape
cons: Very expensive
G HUB software is quite confusing

name: ZOWIE EC2-DW Glossy White Review
pros: Enhanced receiver that doubles as a charging dock is a great feature to have
cons: Some people might not like the fact that it uses mechanical switches instead of opticals
Coating can look dirty quite easily (but performs well)

name: Corsair Sabre v2 Pro Review
pros: Includes grip tape and additional mouse feet
Affordable for a flagship mouse from a big brand
cons: The switches are mechanical, but don’t feel amazing
Side buttons aren’t great
Pre-applied feet are a bit too scratchy

name: VAXEE NP-01S Ergo Review
pros: Web-based driver is clean and easy to use
cons: Expensive
Battery life could be better
No extras (like grip tape or additional feet) in the box
Side buttons could sit a bit higher

name: ZOWIE EC2-DW Review
pros: Enhanced receiver that doubles as a charging dock is a great feature to have
cons: Some people might not like the fact that it uses mechanical switches instead of opticals
Coating can look dirty quite easily (but performs well)

name: Pulsar Xlite V4 eS Review
cons: Sensor performs inconsistently, which is a big deal for an esports mouse
I had some accidental scrolls even when not touching the scroll wheel
Coating is a fingerprint magnet

name: VAXEE XE V2 Wireless Review
pros: Web-based driver is clean, easy to use, and much better than software
cons: Very expensive in some parts of the world (like the EU)
Battery life isn’t great
Replacement feet should be included in the box at this price

name: ZOWIE S2-DW Review
pros: Comes with extra skates as well as a set of alternative skates
Enhanced receiver can also be used as a charging dock
cons: Battery life isn’t the best (this is offset by the charging dock though)
Lack of optical switches might not sit well with everyone

name: Corsair Scimitar Elite Wireless SE Review
pros: Stream Deck integration makes this into a productivity/streaming powerhouse
Dual connectivity (Bluetooth and 2.4GHz) adds further productivity powerhouse points
Tons of extra input options that are quite easy to tell apart
Customizable side panel is a good idea
cons: Main buttons feel a tad mushy
Shape isn’t safe at all

name: ZOWIE U2-DW Review
pros: Comes with a charging dock and an extra (1000Hz receiver)
Tons of extras in the box
cons: Battery life isn’t good (this gets negated by the included charging dock though)
Lack of optical switches might be a dealbreaker to some

name: ZOWIE FK2-DW Review
pros: Lots of extras in the box
Comes with a charging dock, which is handy for high polling rate mice
cons: Battery life is subpar (though this is offset by the charging dock)
Lack of optical switches might be a dealbreaker to some
Side buttons can feel difficult to tell apart at times

name: Endgame Gear OP1w 4K Review
pros: Easy to open the mouse and mod/change switches
Lots of extras in the packaging
cons: Coating is prone to showing fingerprints and smudges
Scroll wheel is a bit too easy to press
Grip on the scroll wheel can be better

name: VAXEE NP-01S V2 Wireless Review
cons: Battery life could be better
I’d love to see replacement feet in the box

name: NZXT Lift Elite Review
cons: Feet feel a bit scratchy on some pads
Main buttons feel a bit mushy due to a combination of post travel and post-click wobble
Back side button feels spongy and travels inside the shell when pressed at the edges

name: ZOWIE ZA13-DW Review
pros: Comes with extra skates and alternative skates
Included enhanced receiver doubles as a charging dock, which is nice
cons: Battery life isn’t great
Use of mechanical switches might disappoint some

name: VAXEE E1 Wireless Review
cons: Clicks might be too light for some
Expensive
Battery life isn’t great

name: Lamzu Maya X Review
cons: Bottom of the mouse could be solid (or at least could be made to protect the scroll wheel from debris a bit better)
Side buttons can be crispier

name: Fnatic x Lamzu Maya 8K Review
cons: Software feels and looks a little cheap
I would prefer a mouse with a solid bottom, even if it’s a bit heavier

name: Razer DeathAdder V3 HyperSpeed Review
cons: Coating could be better at handling sweat
Only 1000Hz out of the box, needs a separate dongle for higher polling rates

name: VAXEE XE-S Wireless Review
cons: Battery life could be better
Expensive

name: NZXT Lift 2 Ergo Review
pros: Pro-level specs for a budget price
cons: Large shape might not suit everyone
Exterior parts of the shell can grind on softer mousepads or when applying a lot of pressure on the mouse

name: Razer Viper V3 Pro Review
pros: 8KHz wireless polling rate out of the box
New shape is a lot safer
cons: Expensive
Side buttons feel a bit mushy

name: VAXEE ZYGEN NP-01 Wireless Review
cons: Side travel on pressed-down buttons can get annoying

name: ZOWIE U2 Review
cons: Coating is a fingerprint and hand oil magnet
Lack of optical switches might come as a disappointment to some
Lacking higher polling rate options is a bit of a bummer in today’s market
Very expensive in certain parts of the world (such as the EU)

name: VAXEE OUTSET AX Wireless Review
cons: Slight wobble on mouse 2 when holding the button
Mouse button 5 has too much post travel

name: Fnatic x Lamzu Thorn Review
cons: Software downloading process is a bit finnicky
Some creaking when applying pressure

name: Pulsar X2H Review
cons: Main buttons feel grindy and inconsistent
Scroll wheel can feel inconsistent when clicking
Coating feels like a step back from previous (limited edition) models
QC issues with the side buttons

name: Logitech G Pro X Superlight 2 Review
pros: Super safe shape that’ll fit anyone
Extremely reliable wireless and sensor performance
Addition of USB-C charging and optical switches addresses the two most commonly heard complaints about the GPX
Sensor calibration tool in G HUB is really handy
cons: Clicks feel heavier than on earlier versions, which might not sit well with everyone
Bottom skate has a different shape, which feels like an unneeded change

name: VAXEE ZYGEN NP-01S Wireless Review
cons: Coating feels a little subpar
Main buttons have some side travel

name: ZOWIE EC3-CW Review
pros: Comes with enhanced receiver that doubles as a charging dock
cons: Loud scroll wheel
Stock feet could be better
High price, especially in the EU
The usage of an older (flawless) sensor might not sit well with everyone

name: VAXEE XE Wireless Review
pros: Extreme focus on competitive gamers with features like competitive mode
Multi-device functionality (you need two receivers for this though)
cons: Coating can get sticky
Some rubbing on the main buttons
Might be too heavy for some
Mouse feet are slightly scratchy

name: Xtrfy M8 Review
cons: Low button height doesn’t really translate to a different feeling in the hands with this mouse
Coating could use some work

name: Zaunkoenig M2K Review
cons: Buttons feel a little mushy
Only comes as a wired mouse
Very expensive

name: SteelSeries Prime Wireless Review
cons: Very heavy clicks
Wheel is too heavy to click
Budget (though flawless) sensor used in a flagship mouse

name: ZOWIE ZA12-C Review
pros: Great shape that’s not often copied
cons: Scroll wheel (even though it has been improved) is still very loud
Coating is a fingerprint and oils magnet

name: VAXEE XE Review
cons: ‘Productivity’ features feel gimmicky and out of place

name: Razer DeathAdder V3 Pro Review
pros: Capable of 4KHz polling rate in wireless mode (with separate dongle)

Side buttons have too much post travel
Shape change might not sit well with everyone
4KHz polling rate not achievable out of the box (you need a separate dongle)

name: Xtrfy MZ1 Wireless
pros: Choice of two included back shells to maximize comfort and grip

Looks a bit goofy

name: Pulsar Xlite Wireless V2 Mini Review
pros: Top tier wireless performance on a budget
cons: Side buttons could use some improvement
Holes in the shell are starting to become outdated and might annoy some
Coating isn’t the best

name: Razer Viper V2 Pro Review
pros: Gen 3 optical switches feel and perform great
Removed right side buttons make for a more consistent grip, but makes the mouse unusable for lefties
Capable of 4KHz polling rate in wireless mode (with separate dongle)
cons: A bit too much post travel on the main buttons
High price
Loses the dock functionality that the V1 had
4KHz polling rate not achievable out of the box (you need a separate dongle)

name: Glorious Model I
pros: Swappable back side button and ‘sniper button’ near the thumb

cons: Buttons are difficult to swap out
Glorious’ software feels cheap
Cable isn’t the best
Subpar side buttons
Not everyone will love the holes in the shell

name: Xtrfy M42 Wireless Review

Holes will annoy some users

name: Pulsar Xlite V2 Wireless Review
cons: Coating could be grippier
Not everyone will like the holes in the shell
Side buttons are a tad mushy

name: Fnatic BOLT Review
